news uk-news what-plan-b-mean-christmas-"Boris Johnson announces move to Plan B for Covid restrictionsByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnson has introduced a new set of Covid rules in the run-up to Christmas in a bid to tackle the fast-spreading Omicron iant.New cases involving the strain are said to be doubling every two to three days and it is on track to become the dominant iant as soon as Christmas, experts say. Masks were already mandatory in some places, such as shops, supermarkets and on public transport, before Mr Johnson announced his aposPlan Bapos on Wednesday.Under the new measures, face coverings must now be worn in England in cinemas, hairdressers, theatres, places of worship, nail salons, massage centres, tattoo studios and some other settings. The NHS Covid Pass will be required for entry to nightclubs and venues with large crowds inside. People in England are also being advised to work from homethey can as part of a bid to drive down coronavirus cases. However, the good news is that families will still be able to come together for Christmas dinner and friends can gather at the pub for a festive drink. What are the new rules From December , face coverings must be worn in most public indoor settings in England, including cinemas, hairdressers, theatres and places of worship. It will also become the law to wear them in nail salons, massage centres, tattoo studios, pharmacies, vets, auction houses, retail galleries, takeaways , estate and lettings agents, high street solicitors, accountants and during driving tests and lessons, Under Plan B, the NHS Covid Pass will also become a requirement for entry to nightclubs and venues with large crowds inside from December . This includes unseated indoor events with  or more people and unseated outdoor venues with , or more iniduals present.New rules also say any contact of a suspected Omicron case must isolate for  days.  How is this dferent from the existing rules  Since November , it has been mandatory to wear masks in shops, supermarkets and on public transport but this rule has now been extended.The Prime Minister did not add any additional travel rules, although these were tightened last month. Arrivals in the UK from anywhere in the world are now forced to take a paid-for PCR test within  hours of their arrival. They must also isolate until the result comes back negative. Since December , people flying back to the UK are also required to take another pre-departure test before they board their flight. The NHS Covid Pass rule for nightclubs is also a sht, with people previously able to show a negative test to enter.  Can I still go to the pub and enjoy Christmas dinner with my family  Yes, pubs will remain open under the plans and you will be able to meet your loved ones for Christmas dinner. There is no indication that the Rule of Six will , meaning there are no limits on social gatherings inside or outside. Boris Johnson rejected the suggestion that festive parties and nativity plays should be cancelled during Wednesdayaposs Downing Street press conference. It means parties are allowed but office work is discouraged.Last Christmas the rules looked very dferent, with a tiered system of restrictions in place across England. People were told to stay at home in London, south-east and east England as they were placed in Tier . Households in other parts of the country were allowed to mix on December , although long-distance travel was discouraged. This year it looks like the rules will not be as strict, although the Prime Minister has refused to rule out a Christmas lockdown so there is still a chance things could change.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter When will Plan B end  The measures announced on Wednesday will be reviewed on January  and the government will update Parliament. Regulations will then “sunset” on January , Health Secretary Sajid Javid told MPs. But both of these days could be brought forward or pushed back so they’re not actually massively relevant.We can glean some information from the criteria for triggering Plan B in the first place.The government will likely base its decision to lt restrictions on the state of the NHS, the link between hospitalisation and infections, vaccine efficacy and immunity, and the impact of new iants. story: Who is classied as a key worker and who can go to work under Plan B  Full list of jobsAs prime minister Boris Johnson confirms the move to Plan B, the guidance states that people must work from home, where possible. So, who classies as a key worker and will still need to go to their workplace From teachers to nurses, find out who is classied as a key worker Image: Getty ImagesBySurena ChandeSEO Editor:,  Dec | comments Following rising cases of the highly transmittable Omicron Covid iant and growing concerns for the NHS, Boris Johnson announced that Plan B restrictions would be introduced from Monday, December , . During a press conference on Wednesday, December , the prime minister advised that from Monday, employees should work from homethey can. In addition to the recent rules on mandatory face masks, another measure that is being introduced under Plan B Covid is mandatory NHS Covid passports for places such as nightclubs and indoor events.The alternative to showing your NHS Covid pass at events and nightclubs is that youaposll now also be able to show a negative lateral flow test, instead.  With the new rules in place, weaposve got a full list of everyone the government deems as a key, or essential, worker that will be exempt from working from home under Plan B. Who is classied as a key or essential worker under government guidelines  Key workers in the UK are those who are essential for keeping the country running in a range of areas, including in healthcare and education.The governmentaposs coronavirus guidance, in early , outlined the following areas and roles as essential workers.Health and Social careThe government guidance states that this stretches across roles such as: doctorsnurses midwives paramedics social workers care workers volunteers in health and social care the support and specialist staff required to maintain the UK’s health and social care sector Additionally, it comprises those working as part of the health and social care supply chain. This includes producers and distributors of medicines and medical and personal protective equipment. Education and childcare The following workers in education and childcare will still need to go to work, unless instructed otherwise:childcare support and teaching staff social workers specialist education professionals who must remain active during the coronavirusresponse to deliver this approachKey public services  Areas including journalism and the justice system also fall under the key worker category, with government guidance listing the following roles:those essential to the running of the justice system religious staff charities and workers delivering key frontline services those responsible for the management of the deceased journalists and broadcasters who are providing public service broadcastingLocal and national government This only includes administrative occupations essential for delivering:the coronavirusresponse essential public services, such as the payment of benefits and the certication or checking of goods for import and export , including in government agencies and armsbodiesFood and other necessary goods Workers offering the following skills will be able to attend work:  From police to fire services, this includes:police and support staff Ministry of Defence civilians contractor and armed forces personneloutbreak fire and rescue service employeesNational Crime Agency staff those maintaining border security, prison and probation staff and other national security roles, including those overseasTransport and border Government guidance states: This includes those who will keep the air, water, road and rail passenger and freight transport modes operating during the coronavirusresponse. story: Woman offered better dealshe made it worthwhile for We Buy Any Car creepHarley Gambetta, , wanted to sell her Citreon C so she could buy a new car, but after getting it valued by We Buy Any Car she got more than she bargained forHarley was bombarded with messages from the creepy worker Image: Harley GambettaByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA woman has claimed she was bombarded with unwanted calls and messages from a We Buy Any Car worker after contacting the company - who allegedly offered to make her a aposbetter dealapos in exchange for sexual favours. Harley Gambetta, , said she took her car for an evaluation but she was offered less than she hoped for her Citroen C so she drove home to consider her options. But then, she claims she was bombarded with calls from an unknown number, followed by text messages that explained it was the We Buy Any Car worker from the branch in West Sussex. The messages then became aposcreepyapos as the man allegedly askedshe wanted to meet up, and offered to make Harley a aposbetter dealaposyou make it worthwhile for me.What do you think of the creepy exchange  Let us know in the comments....Harley, an admin worker, said: It was a bit strange really. I went along there for a quote and it was less than I wanted, but I wasnapost annoyed and didnapost really care that much. I said Iaposd let them know and then he kept calling, about two or three times. Then I got all those texts and calls. He said heaposd make me a better dealI made it worth his while - what sort of person thinks someone will come back for a better deal.  Harley said the location of the We Buy Any Car evaluators, in Burgess Hill, near Brighton, is quite out the way and it would have been dark by the time she arrivedshe did go back. She continued: I dread to think what might have happenedI was naive enough to go back to meet him thinking I would get a better deal. The whole episode dragged on over three or four days and made me really anxious. It was a weird thing to do. “There were around half a dozen calls in total and the suggestion I would get more money by making it worthwhile for him is vile. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. “As a young woman it made me want to warn others about the behaviour of this guy because so much dreadful stuff goes on these days. Harley reported the incident to We Buy Any Car who launched an investigation, but she said she was still worried as the man knew her address and had obtained her private information from online records. She continued: I reported him and We Buy Any Car werenapost that great, they just said sorry and theyaposd sort it out. Iaposd recently just moved out with my boyfriend that week and I felt really anxious, I told them - because heaposd seen my form and knew where I live, but they didnapost really care. It was just a bit weird, Iaposm not really angry - I just find it a bit odd. Itaposs not a normal thing to do, regardlessI was out in a nightclub or not, he works for a known company - I would never be so sure of myself to think someone would come back for a better offer. A spokesperson for We Buy Any Car said: The inidual in question was only employed by webuyanycar for a few weeks at the time the accusations were made. Following an immediate investigation, the employee was dismissed due to his gross misconduct. We do not condone the actions taken by him and these actions do not represent the rest of our team. We wholeheartedly apologise to Ms Gambetta for her experience.”.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: woman who fiddled sisters out
story: Toxic woman who fiddled sisters out of £, inheritance to buy nightclub is jailedBelle Parri was described as low, petty, jealous and controlling by one her sisters after she defrauded her siblings of their rightful inheritance after the £, sale of their parents houseBelle Parri was described as a toxic influence Image: WALES NEWS SERVICEByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA woman fiddled her two sisters out of their inheritance to buy a nightclub. Belle Parri, , cheated her own grieving siblings out of £, from the sale of her parents’ house. A court heard she planned on becoming a bar owner - and defrauded her sisters from their rightful inheritance. A family feud developed after her parents George and Linda Slack died within a fortnight of each other in . Parri had been named executor and trustee of their wills - and was obliged to ide the £, proceeds of a house sale up with her two sisters. But instead she transferred the property in Runcorn, Cheshire, into her own name and tried to remortgage it to buy a nightclub.  Prosecutor James Coutts said sisters Caroline Skye and Victoria Kennedy were conned out of thousands - along with four grandchildren who also stood to inherit smaller amounts. Mr Coutts said: “Instead she decided to buy a bar in Denbigh.” He said: “She told her family in no uncertain terms. This was something she was arranging the finance for herself. She assured them it was nothing to do with their parents’ house.” Caernarfon Crown Court heard Parri - known to her family as Alison - was discovered when another family member opened a letter from a finance company. Parri admitted four charges of fraud. Her sister Caroline said Parri had embarked on a “get rich quick scheme” which she had kept secret. She said: “I am determined to be free of her toxic influence.” Sister Victoria said the frauds were a “malignant effort by Alison to orce me from my family”. Speaking after the case, she added: “This is a very complex case.” She described Parri as “low, petty, jealous and controlling” and added: “She really is a piece of work”. Dafydd Roberts, defending, said the fraud was “putting a property at risk of loss, rather than loss.” Judge Nicola Saffman said Parri had show “an entire lack of remorse.” Parri, of Runcorn, was jailed for  months. news us-news enormous-fish-like-half-mutilated-"Freaky giant sunfish could break world recordByGraeme MurrayMatt Wheaton:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA giant fish like “half a mutilated shark” could smash the world record. Rich German and Matt Wheaton were paddle boarding when they encountered an enormous sunfish. They were in the US city of Laguna Beach, Calornia when they made the freaky discovery.Mr German said: “My buddy, Matt, and I were just paddling and came across it… it was hard to miss! title: mysteries black holes explored nasa
story: Mysteries of black holes to be explored as NASA launches its new X-Ray telescopeA SpaceX Falcon  rocket launched at am on Thursday under the IXPE mission which aims to find more information on some of the most extreme wonders of the universe.The IXPE spacecraft is the first satellite dedicated to measuring the polarisation of X-rays from black holes Image: NASA Joel Kowsky HANDOUT EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Dec | commentsNASA has launched a new X-ray telescope designed to unravel the mysteries of black holes and exploding stars in the first space quest of its kind. The Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer mission, or IXPE, began at am on Thursday with hopes of gaining new insight into some of the most extreme objects in the universe. Space enthusiasts can watch live coverage of the launch on NASA TV and the agencyaposs website. The satellite set off into the sky aboard a SpaceX Falcon  rocket from NASAaposs Kennedy Space Centre in Florida. Nasa confirmed IXPE began its orbit around Earth at an altitude of around  miles. The spacecraft separation took place  minutes into the flight and unfurled its solar arrays around one minute later. Lead investigator Martin Weisskopf said: “It is an indescribable feeling to see something you’ve worked on for decades become real and launch into space.  “This is just the beginning for IXPE. We have much work ahead. But tonight, we celebrate. Mr Weisskopf came up with the idea for the spacecraft and has conducted experiments in X-ray astronomy since the s. Three state of the art telescopes are onboard the spacecraft which is a collaborative effort of NASA and the Italian Space Agency. The technology works by measuring X-rays released by black holes and neutron stars, a term which refers to the collapsed centres of supergiant stars. IXPE is not as big as NASAaposs Chandra X-ray observatory but big hopes are resting on the mission.  Space experts say the satellite will reveal more information on cosmic rays which move through space at almost the speed of light. Thomas Zurbuchen, an associate administrator at NASA Headquarters in Washington, said: “IXPE represents another extraordinary first. “Together with our partners in Italy and around the world, we’ve added a new space observatory to our fleet that will shape our understanding of the universe for years to come. Each NASA spacecraft is carefully chosen to target brand new observations enabling new science, and IXPE is going to show us the violent universe around us – such as exploding stars and the black holes at the centre of galaxies – in ways we’ve never been able to see it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NasaItalian Space AgencySpace" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: New Zealand bans smoking with young people prevented from EVER buying cigarettesNew Zealand has banned smoking for future generations with a ban on young people ever buying cigarettes in their letime - health authorities welcomed the crackdown but retailers and tobacco companies say it will play into the hands of criminals on the black market...Young people are to be banned from ever buying cigarettes in New ZealandImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByByron KayeSiddharth Cavale:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsNew Zealand plans to ban young people from ever buying cigarettes in their letime in one of the world’s toughest crackdowns on the tobacco industry, arguing that other efforts to extinguish smoking were taking too long. People aged  and under in  will never be allowed to purchase cigarettes in the Pacic country of five million, part of proposals unveiled on Thursday that will also curb the number of retailers authorised to sell tobacco and cut nicotine levels in all products. “We want to make sure young people never start smoking so we will make it an offence to sell or supply smoked tobacco products to new cohorts of youth,” New Zealand Associate Minister of Health Ayesha Verrall said in a statement. “If nothing changes, it would be decades till Māori smoking rates fall below %, and this government is not prepared to leave people behind.” How will New Zealandaposs smoking ban for young people work  Currently, .% of all New Zealanders aged over  smoke, a proportion that rises to % among indigenous Maori adults, according to government figures. The government will consult with a Maori health task force in the coming months before introducing legislation into parliament in June next year, with the aim of making it law by the end of .  The restrictions would then be rolled out in stages from , beginning with a sharp reduction in the number of authorised sellers, followed by reduced nicotine requirements in  and the creation of the “smoke-free” generation from . The package of measures will make New Zealand’s retail tobacco industry one of the most restricted in the world, just behind Bhutan where cigarette sales are banned outright. New Zealand’s neighbour Australia was the first country in the world to mandate plain packaging of cigarettes in . The New Zealand government said while existing measures like plain packaging and levies on sales had slowed tobacco consumption, the tougher steps were necessary to achieve its goal of fewer than % of the population smoking daily by . The new rules would halve the country’s smoking rates in as few as  years from when they take effect, the government said. Smoking kills about , people a year in New Zealand, making it one of the country’s top causes of preventable death. Four in five smokers started before age , the country’s government said. Vaping, often seen as a safer alternative to smoking and a useful aid to quitting, is also tightly regulated with sales only allowed to over s. Health authorities welcomed the crackdown, while retailers and tobacco companies expressed concern about the impact on their businesses and warned of the emergence of a black market. “We welcome the New Zealand government’s recognition that excessive excise increases disproportionately impact smokers on lower incomes,” tobacco group Imperial Brands said, adding it was concerned about proposals to reduce nicotine levels and eventually prohibit sales. “Prohibitions of any kind tend to play into the hands of criminal traders who peddle unregulated illicit products,” it also said. Dunhill maker British American Tobaccoand Marlboro maker Philip Morris, which has previously said it would stop sales in the countryrequired by law, did not immediately respond to requests for comment.  According to brokerage Citi, BAT is the market leader in New Zealand, with a % share by volume, while Imperial Brands, which sells JPS, Riverstone and Horizon cigarettes, accounts for %, generating about -% of its group earnings before taxes. The government did not detail how the new rules would be policed or whether they would apply to visitors to the country. “Cigarette smoking kills  New Zealanders every day and two out of three smokers will die as a result of smoking,” said New Zealand Medical Association chair Alistair Humphrey in a statement. “This action plan offers some hope of realising our  Smokefree Aotearoa goal, and keeping our tamarikismokefree.” However, the Dairy and Business Owners Group, a lobby group for local convenience stores, said while it supported a smoke-free country, the government’s plan would destroy many businesses. “This is all  per cent theory and zero per cent substance,” the group’s chairman, Sunny Kaushal, told Stuff.co.nz. “There’s going to be a crime wave. news world-news screaming-tourists-run-cover-five-"Mexico: Police seize jet skis following incidentByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsTourists were seen scrambling for cover after gunfire broke out on the beach at a family-friendly resort. Five attackers showed up at the four-star Oasis Palm hotel in Cancun, Mexico on jet skis before opening fire, Lucio Hernández Gutiérrez, the chief of police of the coastal state of Quintana Roo, said. The jet skis were found a mile away on a beach and seized. Rick Lebassa, an American tourist who witnessed the terrying attack, said two or three gunmen appeared to be shooting into the air with pistols. He said: “There were two guys and maybe even a third, who came in on jet skis, and what I saw was them shooting up into the sky.  “I did not see any shots coming in toward the shoreline.” Andy Guyrich and Kerry Arms, who were also visiting from the US, described the scene. He said: “We just had to hit the deck.” Kerry added: “There was a delayed reaction for about maybe five seconds, then everybody started scrambling and screaming and crying, and running. The terrying shooting is the latest in a series of incidents in the tourist hotspot in the same week.  Footage shows a special battalion of National Guard troops patrolling the beach after they were assigned to protect the area. They are seen with bulletproof vests, helmets and assault rles while walking through the crowded beach. It comes after how hero hotel guests brandished poles as a rain of gunfire killed two near a Day of the Dead party in Mexico.  The rain of bullets caused hotel guests to run for cover after a fight broke out between drug gangs on a beach at the Hyatt Ziva Riviera resort. Former NBC executive Mike Sington, who is staying at the resort told how guests were relaxing on the beach and playing volleyball when the incident happened.He posted on Twitter : Guests are telling me they were playing volleyball on the beach, gunman approached firing gun. The holiday horror saw some guests run for cover, but others grabbed poles ready to defend themselves against the cartel attack. One tourist told CNN: I was by the pool when multiple successive gunshots occurred. It went on for a little while and everyone dove for cover. We manned the entrances to the basement and were given metal sticks, even a pedestal bathroom sink, to defend ourselves. news world-news woman--jumps-ft-building-"Moscow: Man arrested after woman jumps from buildingByLeigh Mcmanus:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A -year-old woman was forced to jump ft into snow to escape a ‘rapist’ who was on her trail and allegedly had two other women tied up in his flat. Harrowing CCTV shows the moment the suspect is then seen running towards his gravely-wounded victim seconds before he stabs her, it is alleged. Eyewitnesses seen running from the attacker called police who later detained a man identied as -year-old Tolibchon Aminov. He is now under criminal investigation for rape, attempted murder and the kidnapping of two other women, aged  and , who were tied up with duct tape in the apartment from which victim had jumped.  The suspect was shown at a crime reenactment at the spot where the woman fell telling investigators: I stabbed her twice. With a kne. This way. Then I ran away.” He demonstrates on a mannequin how he allegedly attacked the woman. The Russian Investigative Committee said Aminov - whose job was renovating flats - “used violence against [the woman] and beat her up, after which he raped her.  “The victim, fleeing from the accused, jumped from the height of the fourth floor. “The man, with intent to kill her looked for a sharp object, went downstairs and inflicted multiple wounds on her, after which he fled.” The -year-old woman is in a “serious” condition in hospital with a fractured pelvis and stab wounds. The suspect, a Tajikistan citizen, has been detained for two months pending further investigations. title: woman who lost dad sister
story: Woman who lost dad and sister in volcano eruption marks day family was ripped apart’Stephanie Browitt, , survived with third-degree burns but lost her sister Krystal, , and dad Paul. She has marked her burnversary by reflecting on the day her family was ripped apartStephanie Browitt suffered burns to  per cent of her bodyByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA burn survivor who lost her sister and father to a volcano eruption has marked her “burnversary” by reflecting on the day her family were “ripped apart”. Stephanie Browitt, , was with her sister Krystal, , and dad Paul, when a volcano erupted on the coast of Whakatane on New Zealand’s North Island on December , . Stephanie survived with third-degree burns to  per cent of her body but her sister and Paul were killed along with  other people on the island at the time. Her mother Marie had stayed behind on the Ovation of the Seas cruise ship and watched on helplessly as tragedy struck. Stephanie, who now wears a protective face mask, posted photos of her family on Thursday to mark the occasion.  She wrote: “Today marks two years since the incident my family and I were a part of. The day that ripped us apart. For a lot of burn survivors they call it their “burnversary”, a day where they can celebrate their achievements, accomplishments and the fact that they survived such awful tragedy’s on this very date. “I truly want to celebrate all that I have accomplished since I was severely burnt, just like other burn survivors do.  “Unfortunately today’s not only the day I survived the unimaginable, it’s the day I lost my dad, Paul and sister, Krystal. It’s the day that they were taken from us.” Stephanie, who has become an advocate for burns survivors since the incident, said her accomplishments mean nothing” when she cannot share them with her lost loved ones. She continued: “Everyday I question why we couldn’t have gone through this extremely hard journey together, why they couldn’t be here also.  “I’m extremely grateful that I was able to make it back home to my mum, but I’m also heartbroken that only I made it back. We are a family of four, not two. “My heart hurts when I remember what I felt that day, but it hurts more not knowing what my dad and sister felt, that I wasn’t next to them during their last moments.” She described the past two years as a period of “loss, pain and never ending grief” and said she missed her dad and sister every day “so much it kills me”.  In November , New Zealand’s workplace safety watchdog charged  parties - including tour operators and the island’s owners - with failings. All defendants have pleaded not guilty but they could be liable for millions of dollars in fines. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. title: battling star hold title favourites
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Red Star ed home with a point after a battling performance against league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie on Saturday November .Star stung the hosts at Cowan Park, Barrhead, with an excellent start to the match, forcing a succession of corners before the ever-dangerous Coll McCallum finished after an excellent delivery by Craig Aitken.The visitors doubled their lead after  minutes when Craig Aitken broke clear down the left and finished with an excellent effort into the goalkeeper’s far corner to put Star - ahead.Star were under pressure for much of the remainder of the half but always carried a threat on the break, with Stuart MacLean’s pace causing the home side no end of problems.Into the second half, Arthurlie forced their way back into the match and pulled a goal back after a rare defensive lapse by Star on  minutes. Star failed to clear the danger from a cross and the unfortunate Coll McCallum erted into his own net past Leon Murphy.The Arthurlie equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when winger Sean Ross cut inside before unleashing a spectacular effort into the top corner.The hosts would have been expected to go on and win the game from here but the Star defence remained well-organised and resolute and a fine goalkeeping performance from Leon Murphy ensured the Lochgilphead side ed home with a well-earned point.Star put their unbeaten league record on the line on Saturday November  when they welcome fellow Argyll side Cardross to the Joint Campus G. Kick-off pm.PIC:The SAFL Division One table after last weekend#s matches. no_aStar_LeagueTable

title: work-start-soon-gala-fairydean-rovers-stand
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers hope to reopen their iconic Netherdale Stand for the start of next season.The Peter Womersley designed building has been closed since winter  due to public health and safety concerns associated with spalling concrete.A structural assessment was initially conducted in  highlighting the required repairs needed to the stand.Concrete Repairs Limitedhas been appointed to carry out a range of improvements to the category A listed building. The work includes concrete repairs to the stand and turnstiles, drainage improvements and aesthetic enhancements around the stand to restore some of its original features.The work will be funded by Scottish Borders Council within this yearrsquos capital budget along with a contribution from the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Community Trust.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoAnyone who is familiar with the town of Galashiels will recognise the iconic architecture of the Netherdale Stand and its importance to the town.ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to see work on repairing the building to its former glory progress with the appointment of an experienced contractor.ldquoEnsuring its long-term future by carrying out these necessary refurbishments will allow future generations to benefit from it andthe stand to its former glory.Murray Souter, regional director for Scotland at Concrete Repairs Limited, said: ldquoConcrete Repairs Limited are delighted to be entrusted with the refurbishment of this iconic structure and our team are looking forward to spending the spring and summer months of  in Galashiels working.ldquoTogether with Scottish Borders Council and their design team, we willthe stand to its original glory, looking great, structurally sound, and ready to cope with a full complement of excited Gala Fairydean Rovers fans.The news was also welcomed by Ross Buchan, chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Community Trust..removeHe said: ldquoThe stand repair project has been a long journey which began for us in October . The stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoWe have now reached a signicant stage on this journey, where, Scottish Borders Council have appointed of the principal contractor to carry out the works. We welcome Concrete Repairs Limitedonto the project and look forward to working in cooperation and partnership with them also.ldquoIt will be a day to celebrate when the stand is opened to the public, club and community where we can once again make full use of this very important facility.ldquoThe project has benefitted from working in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: weekend-rugby-round-up
story: The weather affected this weekendrsquos rugby card with a number of games postponed and one abandoned.In the Premiership, Hawick won the Borders derby beating Selkirk - at Philiphaugh. Kieran Clarkrsquos penalty gave the Souters the lead before Kirk Ford replied with a try which he converted to give the visitors a - half-time lead.Another Clark penalty reduced the deficit before referee Michael Todd awarded a penalty try to Hawick which Ford converted.A third Clark penalty finished the scoring.Jed-Forest travelled to Glasgow where they lost - to the Hawks. Captain Gregor Young suffered a rib injury forcing a change in formation then Paulo Ferreira saw yellow for a high tackle before Glasgow scored a converted try.Selkirk responded with a try from Lewis Young which Gary Munro converted then another penalty from Munro gave the Borderers a - lead.A converted try and a penalty from the Hawks secured the victory despite late pressure from Glasgow.In National League Division One Biggar beat Stirling Wolves - at Hartree Mill, Gala beat Ayr - at Netherdale, Kelso lost - to Highland in Inverness and the Melrose game against Boroughmuir was abandoned.In National League Division Two, Peebles game against Kirkcaldy was postponed.In National League Division Three Berwickrsquos game against Murrayfield Wanderers was abandoned.In National East League One Duns lost - to Broughton.In National East League Two Hawick Lindenrsquos game against Leith was postponed.In National East League Three Earlston lost - to Edinburgh Northern.In Reserve East League One Selkirk A lost - to Hawick Force at home and Jed-Forest A lost - away to Stewartrsquos Melville in the capital.In Reserve East League Two Kelso Sharks drew - with Gala A, Melrose Storm beat Preston Lodge - in Prestonpans and Peebles Reds game against Edinburgh Accies was postponed.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Kelso Harlequins beat Morpeth Colts - away from home.

title: social-lunches-fun-games-berwickshire-communities
story: BERWICKSHIRE Housing Associationrsquos BeFriend project is joining forces with Abundant Borders to take its Lunch Plus programme to towns and villages across the district.Abundant Borders first started Social Lunches in Coldstream in , with regular visits from BHA BeFriend ndash befrienders, befriendees and staff. Following the success of these weekly events it was decided to take these lunches to other communities across Berwickshire.With support from Berwickshire Alliance, and thanks to Scottish Government Covid Recovery Funding, this is now happening and each Thursday, Lunch Plus pops up in a dferent village! Abundant Borders staff and volunteers prepare homemade soup and sandwiches and BHA BeFriend arrange a iety of games and activities for everyone to enjoy.Karen Birch, Chief Officerat Abundant Borders, said: ldquoThe feedback has been incredible, and it is wonderful to be able to support even our most isolated villages and bring hearty food and good cheer to residents.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to be working so closely with the wonderful folk at BHA BeFriend and to be taking social lunches, fun and games to communities across Berwickshire. It is lovely to see people getting back out into their communities, meeting friends, chatting, enjoying freshly prepared food and having a bit of fun together after the couple of years that we have all had.Terri Bearhope, BeFriend Project Co-ordinator, said: ldquoItrsquos so good to be able to see people out and about again. Wersquove had fantastic feedback from people attending and we know that theyrsquore loving the chance to see old friends and meet new ones.ldquoAbundant Borders have been amazing, and their food is wonderful, second to none. The village halls have also been really supportive, not only do they let use their facilities, wersquove had committee members attending the lunches too.So far Lunch Plus events have been held in Grantshouse, Cockburnspath, Preston, Chirnside and Gordon and Foulden with others planned at Burnmouthand Greenlaw . They will also restart again in January.

title: yorkshire-building-society-donate-1955-jedburgh-charity
story: JEDBURGH based charity Jed Hearts Here has received a donation of almost pound, from the Yorkshire Building Society Charitable Foundation after being nominated by colleagues at the Societyrsquos Berwick upon Tweed agency for financial support.Jed Hearts Here is a local charity run by volunteers based in Jedburgh.They started in  and their initiative was to raise funds to provide the local community with as many Public Access Defibrillatorsas possible.They also deliver training to the general public on how to work the PADrsquos should anyone ever find themselves in the situation of having to use one of these to assist in potentially saving someonersquos le until paramedics arrive.They work hard to fundraise to be able to provide this equipment  training to the community free of charge.The pound, donation to Jed Hearts Here will be used to purchase training equipment that will enable them to go out into the community at organised training events.Hope Leer, manager of Yorkshire Building Societyrsquos agency in Berwick upon Tweed, said: ldquoWe are proud to be able to support Jed Hearts Here in our community in the Scottish Borders with a donation from Yorkshire Building Society Charitable Foundation. The work that they are doing to support provide this le saving equipment is giving a real benefit to their local community.Lynn Dixon, chairperson of Jed Hearts Here, said: ldquoThis donation from Yorkshire Building Society Charitable Foundation will make a huge dference to our charity and to the Jedburgh Community. title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly update to Parliament today amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant, describing the situation as "another serious moment" of the pandemic.Last week the Scottish government urged people to tighten their compliance with the rules in order to curb the spread of the iant.Scotland also introduced travel restrictions in a four nation approach with the other UK countries.Earlier on Tuesday prime minister Boris Johnson said that preliminaryindications suggested the new iant was more transmissible than Delta.This was addressed bythe first minister today who outlinedwhat scientists so far understand about Omicron.As Omicron continues to cause uncertainty in the run-up to Christmas, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today.... Current protections to remain in placeNo changes will be made to the current regulations, however the Scottish government wants the public to tighten compliance with the regulations.The ruleswill be monitored daily due to the new iant, with the government able to bring in further measuresrequired.The first minister said the Scottish government will seek to do what is necessary to prevent the problem, and will therefore "strive" to act both proportionately andpreventatively evenat the cost of popularity."For the Scottish Government, our first principle will be to seek to do what is necessary to keep the country as safe as possible, eventhat is sometimes at the expense of being popular."And second, we will strive to get the right balance between acting proportionately and acting preventatively.". Rise in overall number of casesCases have risen over the past -daysin all age cohorts under .The first minister said: "In total, cases amongst under s increased by % in the past week - and since people under  currently account for more than % of cases overall, that has inevitably driven an increase in the total number of cases recorded.".remove. More details on confirmed Omicron cases in Scotland coming tomorrowMore detailed information onthe number of Omicron cases in Scotland is due tomorrow.In the coming weeks, more data will become available on the hospitalisations and deaths linked to the Omicron iant, with the first minister saying: "In weeks to come - and as the quality of data allows - these reports will also provide details on the vaccination status of, and hospital admissions and deaths associated with, Omicron cases.". Ten fold increase in Omicron in a single weekOmicron cases in Scotland have increased from  to  cases in the space of a week.Like Boris Johnson this morning, Nicola Sturgeon also said that early evidence suggests that the Omicron iant is more transmissible than Delta.She warned to expect a rapid rise of cases in the coming days..
